newsitem.title: USA: Boeing profits fall, but sales surge in quarter.
newsitem.headline: Boeing profits fall, but sales surge in quarter.

text.p: Boeing Co. sales surged but profits fell in the second quarter as the aerospace giant struggled to keep up with rising demand for commercial jets, the company said Monday.

The world's largest commercial aircraft maker said net income for the quarter fell to $399 million, or 55 cents a share, excluding the effects of an employee stock plan, from $468 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier.
Sales surged 48 percent to $9.29 billion from $6.28 billion as the company ramped up commercial aircraft production and expanded its space and missiles business.

The results for the quarter ending June 30 fell below the Wall Street consensus estimate of 59 cents a share, according to First Call, which tracks analysts' forecasts. Boeing stock was off $1.56 at $54.50 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

Industry analysts said Boeing's profit margins were being squeezed by the company's efforts to ramp up production to a record 43 jets a month early in 1998 from 22.5 a month at the beginning of this year.

"There's no question that this ramp-up is a far greater challenge than investors expected and the company was anticipating," said Peter Jacobs, an analyst at Ragen MacKenzie in Seattle. "They can get over this. It's just a matter of time."

Some analysts said investors also were nervous about a looming meeting of the European Commission on Wednesday, when it is expected to vote to block Boeing's planned $14 billion merger with McDonnell Douglas Corp.

After slashing employment by more than one-third in the early 1990s, Boeing has been expanding its work force by adding jobs and making acquisitions, including the purchase of Rockewell International Corp.'s aerospace buusiness last year.

Boeing Chairman Phil Condit said in a news release that the rapid increase in production has resulted in "a substantial increase in employment, material and fabrication demand at the company and its suppliers." High overtime levels and parts shortages have caused a "near-term decline in productivity," he added.

Analysts said profits also are being hurt by high spending on development of new models, such as the next-generation 737 line, and by strong sales of the new 777, which will carry low profit margins for its first several years of service.
Boeing said it expects to spend $1.4 billion on research and development in 1997, up from $1.2 billion last year.

Boeing also said it expects to deliver 340 to 350 commercial jetliners this year, up from a previous projection of 340. Last year, Boeing delivered just 218 jets as the company reached the end of a long industry downturn.
So far this year, Boeing has announced orders for 224 commercial airplanes valued at $15.6 billion, down from 225 airplanes worth $17.6 billion in last year's first half.
Jacobs said he expects Boeing to announce commercial jet orders worth $30 billion to $40 billion this year, compared with last year's record 717 jets worth $53 billion.
But he noted that even $30 billion "is still a very high level by any kind of historical standards."

Boeing's results for the latest quarter were stated excluding the effects of the company's employee stock plan, which would have trimmed earnings to $334 million, or 48 cents a share. Boeing said results from last year's second quarter were boosted by one-time gains of $176 million, or 25 cents a share.
